revisions.rev:
{{NCAATeamSeason |Mode=Basketball |Year=2009â10 |Prev year=2008â09 |Next year=2010â11 |Team=Clemson Tigers |Image=Clemson University Wordmark.svg |ImageSize=200 |Conference=Atlantic Coast Conference |Division= |ShortConference=ACC |CoachRank= |APRank= |Record=21–11 |ConfRecord=9–7 |HeadCoach=[[Oliver Purnell]] |AsstCoach1=[[Ron Bradley]] |AsstCoach2=Frank Smith |AsstCoach3=Josh Postorino |StadiumArena=[[Littlejohn Coliseum]] |Champion= |BowlTourney=[[2010 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Tournament]] |BowlTourneyResult=First Round }} {{2009â10 ACC men's basketball standings}} The '''2009â10 Clemson Tigers men's basketball team''' represented [[Clemson University]] in the [[2009â10 NCAA Division I men's basketball season|2009â10]] [[college basketball]] season. Their head coach was [[Oliver Purnell]]. The team played its home games at [[Littlejohn Coliseum]] in [[Clemson, SC|Clemson]], [[South Carolina]] and are members of the [[Atlantic Coast Conference]]. All games were produced and [[Radio broadcasting|broadcast locally]] by the [[Clemson Tigers Sports Network]]. The Tigers finished the season 21–11, 9–7 in ACC play. They lost in the first round of the [[2010 ACC Men's Basketball Tournament]]. They received an at-large bid to the [[2010 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament]], earning a 7 seed in the East Region, where they lost to 10-seed [[2009â10 Missouri Tigers men's basketball team|Missouri]] in the first round.
== Pre-season == On Wednesday, May 27, guard [[Terrence Oglesby]] announced he would forego his final two seasons at the school to pursue a professional basketball career. Oglesby appeared in 66 games and scored 777 points in his two seasons at Clemson. Previously, Oglesby played for [[Norway]] at the [[International Basketball Federation]] (FIBA) [[FIBA Europe Under-20 Championship]]. In a press release issued by Clemson University, Oglesby indicated that his time spent playing internationally helped fuel his decision to turn pro.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://clemsontigers.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/052709aaa.html | work=Men's Basketball | publisher=ClemsonTigers.com | title=Oglesby to Leave Clemson to Pursue Professional Basketball Career | accessdate=2009-05-27 }}</ref> Oglesby's departure left an open roster spot which was filled by the commitment of shooting guard Noel Johnson, a former [[USC Trojans men's basketball|USC]] commitment.<ref>[http://rivals.yahoo.com/ncaa/basketball/news?slug=ap-clemson-johnson&prov=ap&type=lgns Johnson turns to Clemson after Floyd leaves USC]</ref>
On Tuesday, August 18, [[ESPN]] announced that Clemson will serve as one of the host sites for the networkâs popular basketball series, [[College GameDay (basketball)|College GameDay]], during the [[2009â10 NCAA Division I men's basketball season]]. Two one-hour shows (11:00 am and 8:00 pm Eastern) will originate from [[Littlejohn Coliseum]] on Jan. 23, 2010 for the Clemson vs. [[2009â10 Duke Blue Devils men's basketball team|Duke]] game. This is Clemsonâs first appearance on ESPN College GameDay. The series, which is in its sixth season, will make four first-time stops in 2010. Other first-time hosts include Illinois, Kansas State and Washington. The Clemson/Duke game will be one of two ACC tilts featured this season, with the other being North Carolina at Duke on Mar. 6.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://clemson.scout.com/2/889607.html | work=CUTigers | publisher=Scout.com | title=Gameday coming to Clemson | accessdate=2009-08-18 }}</ref>
On Sunday, October 26, 2008, members of the [[Atlantic Coast Conference|ACC]] Media were polled and picked Clemson to finish third in the conference behind North Carolina and Duke.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.theacc.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/102509aab.html | work=Men's Basketball | publisher=The ACC | title=Media Splits Top Spot in 2009-10 ACC Preseason Poll | accessdate=2008-10-25 }}</ref>
==Regular season==
On December 2, 2009, [[Illinois Fighting Illini men's basketball|Illinois]] came back from a 23-point second-half deficit to upset the No. 18 Tigers, 76-74 at Littlejohn Coliseum. The victory was the biggest comeback win in school history and was also notable as it helped the [[Big Ten]] win their first [[ACC â Big Ten Challenge]] in eleven tries.<ref>[http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/34248575/ns/sports-college_basketball/ Illinoisâ monster 2nd half stuns No. 18 Clemson]</ref>
On December 6, 2009, Clemson beat rival South Carolina 72-61, extending their winning streak over the Gamecocks to six games. Carolina leads the overall series, 86-74.
On January 3, 2010, the No. 21 Tigers managed only 12 points in the first half as they lost to No. 7 [[Duke Blue Devils men's basketball|Duke]] for the 13th straight time at [[Cameron Indoor Stadium]], 74-53. Clemson had as many fouls as points in the opening period, and their scoring total and shooting percentage (5-30, 17%) were the lowest for a half in Oliver Purnell's seven years as head coach.<ref>[http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=300030150 Duke holds No. 18 Clemson to 12 first-half points in blowout win]</ref>
On January 13, 2010, the No. 19 Tigers ended a 10-game losing streak to North Carolina by defeating the No. 13 Tar Heels, 83-64 at Littlejohn Arena. It was the second largest margin of victory ever for the Tigers over the Tar Heels. The most being a 20-point 93-73 win in 1976-77, [[Tree Rollins]]' senior season.<ref>[http://clemsontigers.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/recaps/011410aam.html Clemson vs. North Carolina Postgame Notes]</ref> Clemson then followed the win with a 73-70 win at NC State, ending a streak of 13 consecutive losses in the game following a victory over a top 25 team.<ref>[http://clemsontigers.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/recaps/011610aaa.html Tigers Top North Carolina State, 73-70]</ref>
[[File:2010 College Gameday at Clemson.jpg|right|thumb|College GameDay live broadcast from Littlejohn Coliseum <small>(Jan 23, 2010)</small>]]On January 23, 2010, [[ESPN]]'s [[College GameDay (basketball)|College GameDay]] broadcasted live from [[Littlejohn Coliseum]] for the first time. Afterward, GameDay host [[Digger Phelps]] said of the broadcast at Clemson: "It was the best". The crowd was so loud during the broadcast that the production director requested that the crowd keep the noise down when cameras were rolling.<ref>[http://clemson.scout.com/a.z?s=46&p=2&c=940271 Duke Dominates PHELPS: "It was the best"]</ref> The day culminated in a 47-60 loss to Duke, the lowest point total for Duke thus far this season,<ref>[http://statsheet.com/mcb/teams/duke/schedule?season=2008-2009 Duke Blue Devils]</ref> and the lowest point total of a Clemson team at home since the 2003-04 season, Oliver Purnell's first at Clemson.<ref>[http://ncaabasketball.fanhouse.com/2010/01/24/duke-routs-clemson/ Duke Dominates With Defense, Routs Clemson]</ref>
==Postseason== ===ACC Tournament=== Clemson entered the [[2010 ACC Men's Basketball Tournament|ACC Tournament]] as the No. 6 seed with a 9-7 record in the ACC regular season. The Tigers lost their opening game to No. 11 seed NC State 59-57, dropping their record in the tournament to 16-57 all-time with 43 of their losses coming in the first round. Clemson remains the only original member of the ACC to have never won the tournament.<ref>[http://scores.espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=300700228 North Carolina State drops Clemson from ACC tourney]</ref>
===NCAA Tournament=== Clemson entered the tournament as the No. 7 seed in the East Region, but was knocked out in the opening round by a lower-seeded team for the third straight year, losing 86-78 to No. 10 seed Missouri. The loss dropped Oliver Purnell to 0-6 all-time in NCAA Tournament games as a head coach for three different schools.<ref>[http://rivals.yahoo.com/ncaa/basketball/recap?gid=201003190120 Missouri stifles Booker, beats Clemson 86-78]</ref>
